climbs.name: Anchor
climbs.fa: FA: Brian Rhothery 1960. FFA: Edouard Pierre Gagnon 1978

content.description:
Climb up the ramp to the left to gain the left facing corner. The corner takes small gear and will lead you to a superb hand crack roof exit. A must do!



Access from the top of Mont King or climb one of the lower routes to acces the ledge system of the Crown Sector.

Belay from the left most anchor on the crown ledge.

Trad

Climb up the Anchor route and instead of going up the left facing corner, go right and follow the horizontal crack until your at the right end of the wall and facing a finger crack above the Crown direct. Climb up the crack to a two bolt anchors.


1 No3. Small cams + nuts. Runners

Get by Imperiale's anchor on the slab (1 bolt) then climb a short section of fist crack to a comfortable ledge and anchor. Follow the thin crack to the right(small gear) to a big horizontal. Move a bit left then reach the obvious slightly left leaning crack system. Jug and lie back your way to top. Beautiful climbing on quality rock! Reach its start by climbing Imperiale(preferably),Eclipse or Sceptre. Gear up to 2" with a few more small
70m rope 2 raps
60m rope 3 raps

.

.

Lots of runners to avoid drag if not doing the Directe variation.

70m will get you down in two raps using Imperiale's first anchors, but you may have to downclimb one or two meters (5.3) as its really stretched out. 

There may be a better combination of anchors to get down in two raps, otherwise 60m 3 raps.

An easy first few moves yield to a thought-provoking section on iron-rust colored rock. Great, varied crack climbing up to an offwidth section. Then as you tired, the seemingly never-ending face yields to a mantle & the anchors.

If you are going to rap from the top, you can reach the anchors on the slab section below with a 70m. Then a 2nd rap would get you to the ground from there. With a 60m you would likely need 3 rapps.



The paper guidebook is sightly off if you use the belayer's anchors as a mark. If you gained Crown by climbing Imperial (5.9) and skipped its anchor, you arrived at the base of Crown Direct (10a) and an anchor on a small ledge, at the beginning of the Crown wall. From there, an easy traverse to the climber's left passes a large boulder (5.7, might want to plug a piece of gear) and leads to a 2nd belayer's anchor on a larger ledge. That 2nd anchor, roughly midway on the Crown wall and just before the ledge angles upward to the trees, is right at the base of this route (Diamants de la Couronne). The guidebook erronously marks that anchor as being before the large boulder.


Regular rack. Gear is decent enough, though the offwidth section might feel committing if that's at you limit. Perhaps a larger piece (#4 or #5) could protect that section. However the gear below is good and the offwidth section isn't too long. Decent route to push the grade.

Crowning the top of Mont King,Le Mur offers several jewel like routes that will keep your interest by the airy atmosphere it holds.
Accessed by climbing most of the lines of the Imperiale area or from hiking the trail to panoramic viewpoints.
One out of three routes of that wall are classic! But the most appreciated and climbed is definitely The Crown Directe 10a. Make sure you don't miss Diadème 10c, Diamants de la Couronne 10d and Sa Majesté 12c....
Unforgettable experience guaranteed!!!

Couronnant le sommet du Mont King, Le Mur propose plusieurs itinéraires joyaux qui vous séduiront par l'atmosphère aérienne qu'ils offrent.On y accède en escaladant la plupart des lignes de Impériale ou en empruntant le sentier qui mène aux points de vue panoramiques.
Un tracé sur trois de ce mur est classique ! Mais la plus appréciée et la plus escaladée est sans aucun doute The Crown Directe 10a. Ne manquez pas Diadème 10c, Diamants de la Couronne 10d et Sa Majesté 12c....
Expérience mémorable garantie !!!
